title: Improving Chemical Composition Measurements from Microscale to Atomic Scale with Fused Multi-Modal Microscopy
content: Critical temperature and superheating field of A15 superconductors can change dramatically with stoichiometry. For example, the critical temperature of Nb3Sn reduces by half for less than a 5% change in the atomic Sn concentration [1]. Sn-deficient grains are commonplace with current growth methods [2]. Previously, Slice and View tomography has been attempted on Nb3Sn. However, the EDS resolution was not sufficient to measure and quantify the Sn-deficient regions in the Nb3Sn film [3]. Another common defect impacting superconductivity is the anti-site defect pair, for which theoretical calculations have shown the lowest energy formation [4]. However, the experimental visualization of anti-site defects in Nb3Sn has yet to be reported. To address these questions, in this work, we combine electron imaging and X-ray spectroscopy across multiple length scales. By collecting different types of signals carrying complementary properties, a more complete and improved understanding of the materialâ€™s structure and composition can be achieved [5].
